<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Lentil skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Lentil</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
</p>
<div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Taxobox/core&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Taxobox/core (page does not exist)">Template:Taxobox/core</a></div>
<p>The <b>lentil</b> (<i><b>Lens culinaris</b></i>) (International Feed Number, 5-02-506) is an edible <a href="/wiki/Pulse_(legume)" title="Pulse (legume)">pulse</a>. It is a bushy <a href="/wiki/Annual_plant" title="Annual plant">annual plant</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Fabaceae" title="Fabaceae">legume</a> family, grown for its <a href="/wiki/Lens_(geometry)" title="Lens (geometry)">lens</a>-shaped <a href="/wiki/Seed" title="Seed">seeds</a>. It is about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> tall and the seeds grow in <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">pods</a>, usually with two seeds in each.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Background"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Background</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Types"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Types</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Nutritional_value_and_health_benefits"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Nutritional value and health benefits</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Production"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Production</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Diseases"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Diseases</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#In_culture"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">In culture</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Llenties_maig.JPG" title="File:Llenties maig.JPG">File:Llenties maig.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Lentil plants in the field before flowering</div></div></div>
<p>Lentils have been part of the human diet since the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aceramic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aceramic (page does not exist)">aceramic</a> (before <a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">pottery</a>) <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> times, being one of the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic_founder_crops" title="Neolithic founder crops">first crops domesticated</a> in the Near East.  Archeological evidence shows they were eaten 9,500 to 13,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-zeldes_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zeldes-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lentil colors range from yellow to red-orange to green, brown and black.<sup id="cite_ref-zeldes_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zeldes-1">[1]</a></sup> Lentils also vary in size (e.g. Masoor lentils, shown in photos here), and are sold in many forms, with or without the skins, whole or split.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Types">Types</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Illustration_Lens_culinaris0.jpg" title="File:Illustration Lens culinaris0.jpg">File:Illustration Lens culinaris0.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Illustration of the lentil plant, 1885</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lentils_red_and_brown.jpg" title="File:Lentils red and brown.jpg">File:Lentils red and brown.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Red and brown comparison</div></div></div>
<ul>
<li> Brown/Spanish pardina
</li>
<li> French green/<a href="/w/index.php?title=Le_Puy_Green_lentil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Le Puy Green lentil (page does not exist)">puy lentils</a> (dark speckled blue-green)
</li>
<li> Green
</li>
<li> Black/beluga
</li>
<li> Yellow/tan lentils (red inside)
</li>
<li> Red Chief (decorticated yellow lentils)
</li>
<li> Eston Green (Small green)
</li>
<li> Richlea (medium green)
</li>
<li> Laird (large green)
</li>
<li> Petite Golden (decorticated lentils)
</li>
<li> Masoor (brown-skinned lentils which are orange inside)
</li>
<li> Petite crimson/red (decorticated masoor lentils)
</li>
<li> <i>Macachiados</i> (big Mexican yellow lentils)
</li>
</ul>
<p>The seeds require a cooking time of 10 to 40 minutes, depending on the variety—shorter for small varieties with the husk removed, such as the common red lentil — and have a distinctive, earthy flavor. Lentils are used throughout <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Asia (page does not exist)">South Asia</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mediterranean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mediterranean (page does not exist)">Mediterranean</a> regions and <a href="/wiki/West_Asia" title="West Asia" class="mw-redirect">West Asia</a>. They are frequently combined with <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, which has a similar cooking time. A lentil and rice dish is referred to in western Asia as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mujaddara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mujaddara (page does not exist)">mujaddara</a></i> or <i>mejadra</i>. Rice and lentils are also cooked together in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Khichdi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Khichdi (page does not exist)">khichdi</a></i>, a popular dish in the Indian subcontinent (India and Pakistan); a similar dish, <i><a href="/wiki/Kushari" title="Kushari">kushari</a></i>, made in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egypt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egypt (page does not exist)">Egypt</a>, is considered one of two <a href="/wiki/National_dish" title="National dish">national dishes</a>. Lentils are used to prepare an inexpensive and nutritious <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soup (page does not exist)">soup</a> all over <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">North and South America</a>, sometimes combined with some form of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chicken_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chicken (food) (page does not exist)">chicken</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pork&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pork (page does not exist)">pork</a>.
</p><p>Dried lentils can also be <a href="/wiki/Sprouting" title="Sprouting">sprouted</a> by soaking in water for one day and keeping moist for several days, which changes their nutrition profile.
</p><p>Lentils with husk remain whole with moderate cooking; lentils without husk tend to disintegrate into a thick purée, which leads to quite different dishes.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutritional_value_and_health_benefits">Nutritional value and health benefits</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nutritionalvalue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nutritionalvalue (page does not exist)">Template:Nutritionalvalue</a>
</p><p>With about 30% of their calories from protein, lentils have the third-highest level of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protein_(nutrient)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protein (nutrient) (page does not exist)">protein</a>, by weight, of any legume or nut, after <a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">soybeans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hemp" title="Hemp">hemp</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Proteins include the <a href="/wiki/Essential_amino_acid" title="Essential amino acid">essential amino acids</a> <a href="/wiki/Isoleucine" title="Isoleucine">isoleucine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lysine" title="Lysine">lysine</a>, and lentils are an essential source of inexpensive protein in many parts of the world, especially in <a href="/wiki/West_Asia" title="West Asia" class="mw-redirect">West Asia</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_subcontinent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian subcontinent (page does not exist)">Indian subcontinent</a>, which have large <a href="/wiki/Vegetarianism" title="Vegetarianism">vegetarian</a> populations.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>  Lentils are deficient in two essential amino acids, <a href="/wiki/Methionine" title="Methionine">methionine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cysteine" title="Cysteine">cysteine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> However, sprouted lentils contain sufficient levels of all essential amino acids, including methionine and cysteine.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lentils also contain <a href="/wiki/Dietary_fiber" title="Dietary fiber">dietary fiber</a>, <a href="/wiki/Folate" title="Folate" class="mw-redirect">folate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_B1" title="Vitamin B1" class="mw-redirect">vitamin B<sub>1</sub></a>, and minerals. Red (or pink) lentils contain a lower concentration of fiber than green lentils (11% rather than 31%).<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> <i>Health</i> magazine has selected lentils as one of the five healthiest foods.<sup id="cite_ref-Raymond_2006_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Raymond_2006-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>The low levels of Readily Digestible Starch (RDS) 5%, and high levels of Slowly Digested Starch (SDS) 30%, make lentils of great interest to people with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diabetes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diabetes (page does not exist)">diabetes</a>. The remaining 65% of the starch is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Resistant_starch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Resistant starch (page does not exist)">resistant starch</a> that is classified RS1,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> being a high quality resistant starch, which is 32% <a href="/wiki/Amylose" title="Amylose">amylose</a>.
</p><p>Lentils also have some anti-nutritional factors, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trypsin_inhibitor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trypsin inhibitor (page does not exist)">trypsin inhibitors</a> and relatively high <a href="/wiki/Phytate" title="Phytate" class="mw-redirect">phytate</a> content. Trypsin is an enzyme involved in digestion, and phytates reduce the bio-availability of dietary minerals.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> The phytates can be reduced by soaking the lentils in warm water overnight.
</p><p>Lentils are a good source of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_iron_metabolism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human iron metabolism (page does not exist)">iron</a>, having over half of a person's daily iron allowance in a 100&#160;g serving.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lentiloutput.png" title="File:Lentiloutput.png">File:Lentiloutput.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Worldwide lentil production</div></div></div>
<p>Lentils are relatively tolerant to drought, and are grown throughout the world. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=FAO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FAO (page does not exist)">FAO</a> reported that the world production of lentils for calendar year 2009 was 3.917 million metric tons, primarily coming from Canada, India, Turkey and Australia.
</p><p>About a quarter of the worldwide production of lentils is from <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, most of which is consumed in the domestic market. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada (page does not exist)">Canada</a> is the largest export producer of lentils in the world and <a href="/wiki/Saskatchewan" title="Saskatchewan">Saskatchewan</a> is the most important producing region in Canada. <a href="/wiki/Statistics_Canada" title="Statistics Canada">Statistics Canada</a> estimates that Canadian lentil production for the 2009/10 year is a record 1.5 million metric tons.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Palouse" title="Palouse">Palouse</a> region of eastern <a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_(state)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington (state) (page does not exist)">Washington</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Idaho" title="Idaho">Idaho</a> panhandle, with its commercial center at <a href="/wiki/Pullman,_Washington" title="Pullman, Washington">Pullman, Washington</a>, constitute the most important lentil-producing region in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Montana" title="Montana">Montana</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Dakota" title="North Dakota">North Dakota</a> are also significant lentil growers.<sup id="cite_ref-zeldes_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zeldes-1">[1]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Agricultural_Statistics_Service" title="National Agricultural Statistics Service">National Agricultural Statistics Service</a> reported United States 2007 production at 154.5 thousand metric tons. 
</p>
<table class="sortable wikitable">
<caption> Top 10 Lentil Producing Countries <br />(in metric tons)

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5"> <center> <i>Source: <a href="/w/index.php?title=FAO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FAO (page does not exist)">UN Food &amp; Agriculture Organization</a></i> <sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Diseases">Diseases</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_culture">In culture</span></h2>
<p>The lens (<a href="/wiki/Convex_lens#Types_of_simple_lenses" title="Convex lens" class="mw-redirect">double-convex</a> shaped) is so called because the shape of a lens is basically the same shape as lentils. <i>Lens</i> is the Latin name for lentil.
</p><p>Lentils are mentioned many times in the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a>, the first time recounting the incident in which <a href="/wiki/Jacob" title="Jacob">Jacob</a> purchases the birthright from <a href="/wiki/Esau" title="Esau">Esau</a> with stewed lentils (a "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mess_of_pottage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mess of pottage (page does not exist)">mess of pottage</a>").<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bereavement_in_Judaism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bereavement in Judaism (page does not exist)">Jewish mourning</a> tradition, lentils are traditional as food for mourners, together with boiled <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egg_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egg (food) (page does not exist)">eggs</a>, because their round shape symbolizes the life cycle from birth to death.
</p><p>Lentils were a chief part of the diet of ancient Iranians, who consumed lentils daily in the form of a stew poured over rice.
</p><p>Lentils are also commonly used in <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a> in a stew-like dish called <i>kik</i>, or <i>kik wot</i>, one of the dishes people eat with Ethiopia's national food, <i><a href="/wiki/Injera" title="Injera">injera</a></i> flat bread. Yellow lentils are used to make a non-spicy stew, which is one of the first solid foods Ethiopian women feed their babies.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, lentils are often consumed with <a href="/wiki/Roti" title="Roti">Roti</a>/bread or rice.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, lentils soaked in water and sprouted lentils are offered to Gods in many temples. It is also a practice in South India to give and receive sprouted peas by women who perform <a href="/w/index.php?title=Varalakshmi_Vratam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Varalakshmi Vratam (page does not exist)">Varalakshmi Vratam</a>. It is considered to be one of the best foods because the internal chemical structures are not altered by cooking.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>, eating lentils on <a href="/wiki/New_Year%27s_Eve" title="New Year's Eve">New Year's Eve</a> traditionally symbolizes the hope for a prosperous new year, most likely because of their round, coin-like form.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a> narrations, lentils are said to be blessed by seventy Prophets, including Jesus and Mohammed.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>In "<a href="/wiki/Cinderella" title="Cinderella">Cinderella</a>", one of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grimm%27s_Fairy_Tales&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grimm's Fairy Tales (page does not exist)">Grimm's Fairy Tales</a>, Cinderella's stepmother assigns to Cinderella the task of  fishing lentils out of ash. If she succeeds, she may go to the ball.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<p>{{#invoke:Portal|portal}}
</p>
<ul>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Dal" title="Dal">Dal</a></i>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Lentil_soup" title="Lentil soup">Lentil soup</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moujadara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moujadara (page does not exist)">Moujadara</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Lentil_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Lentil Festival (page does not exist)">National Lentil Festival</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Revalenta_arabica&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revalenta arabica (page does not exist)">Revalenta arabica</a>, a 19th-century patent medicine made of lentils
</li>
</ul>

</li>
<li> S S Yadav et al. <i>Lentil: An Ancient Crop for Modern Times</i>. (2007). Springer Verlag. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781402063121" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 9781402063121</a>.
</li>
</ul>
